Author: jeppercrock

Comment: The Republicans will only own all of the negative repercussions if the Democrats persuasively  communicate this to voters now and in the future. And that doesn’t necessarily mean logic and reasoning.   Whatever else you may think of Republicans, they’ve been winning the narrative war for the past twenty-five years (with a short-lived blip in 2008).   Yes, they have Fox News, which serves ostensibly as a wing of the Republican Party, but more than that they are shameless in their Janus-faced style of blaming the Dems for everything. They take no prisoners with their narrative, and it works for enough of the electorate to give them victories.   Meanwhile…  …the Dems continue to wear gloves while the Republicans wield brass knuckles. Dems can be very right all day on policies, but only election results truly matter.   In the end, elections are won by emotions - not ideas. Trump proved this twice with his fiery word salads, even to the point of having Republicans vote against their own self-interests and belief systems.   The Dems must first do what it takes to win elections and then work to implement their ideas for a fairer and more just society.  Playing fair only works when the opponents acknowledge and agree to the rules. The Republicans have burned the rules book altogether.

Comment: > [Reconciliation starts with the congressional budget resolution. The budget cannot be stalled in the Senate by filibuster, and it does not need the President’s signature.](https://democrats-budget.house.gov/resources/fact-sheet/budget-reconciliation-explainer)  > If the budget calls for reconciliation, it tells certain committees to change spending, revenues, deficits, or the debt limit by specific amounts. Each committee writes a bill to achieve its target, and if more than one committee is told to act, the Budget Committee puts the bills together into one big bill.  > That bill has special status in the Senate. Like the budget, it cannot be filibustered, and only needs a simple majority to pass.
